title: Heavy rains snarl traffic, cause flooding as cold front pushes through Dallas-Fort Worth
summary:
Heavy rain sliced through North Texas early Thursday, flooding streets, snarling rush-hour traffic and putting an emphatic end to a few days of unseasonably warm weather.
The rains arrived along with a cold front before sunrise Thursday and were heavy in parts of the area.
Dallas police shut down Hillcrest Road just south of Royal Lane after heavy rains caused street flooding in Dallas on Thursday, January 16, 2020.
Another flood warning was issued for Elm Fork Trinity River near Carrollton.
The river was expected to crest at 8 feet and cause minor flooding, according to the weather service.

title: Damage Reported in Irving Due to Weather
summary:
A hotel suffered damage after strong winds blew through Irving.
NBC 5 reporter Meredith Yeomans took photos of a Hilton Garden Inn hotel after it had been damaged after Friday evening's storms.
Wind blew siding and insulation off part of the Irving hotel located near Interstate 635 and the President George Bush Turnpike.

No injuries were reported.

title: Las Colinas sale was one of the country’s biggest office deals in 2019

title: Texas recorded more lightning strikes in 2019 than any other state
summary:
In fact, Texas led the nation in lightning strikes last year, with 47,397,975 lightning strikes recorded, according to a new report by Vaisala.
That’s more than three times the second state on the list Oklahoma, which recorded 14,772,145 lightning strikes in 2019.
Texas’ geographic location, humidity, and the state’s massive size make it an annual contender to lead the nation in lightning strikes, according to the report.
When the number of lightning strikes were measured by density per square kilometer, Texas dropped on the list to No.
4, with 69 lightning strikes per square kilometer in 2019.

title: Body found in Irving identified as woman reported missing in Garland
summary:
Updated at 2:32 p.m. Feb. 4: Revised to include the identity of the victim and additional details from police.
A woman found slain near a dumpster Sunday afternoon in Irving has been identified as a missing woman, police said Tuesday.
Jessica Hernandez, 22, was reported missing to Garland police Jan. 26, police said.
Officers found Hernandez’s body in a dumpster enclosure in the 2900 block of North Belt Line Road, near State Highway 183, about 12:40 p.m. Sunday.
KXAS-TV (NBC 5) reported that no suspects have been identified and no arrests have been made.

title: Hidden Ridge developer to pay for building costs of new Irving transit station
summary:
Irving City Council has amended an economic incentive agreement worth $24.3 million with the developer of the Hidden Ridge mixed-use project.The amended agreement stipulates that the developer pay for building costs of a new Dallas Area Rapid Transit light rail station .
That station will be located along the Orange Line near Pioneer Natural Resource’s campus between Carpenter Ranch Road and Green Park Drive, and it is expected to be complete in December.The amended agreement also provides for additional economic incentives that would be unlocked upon the developer’s completion of additional construction projects.The Hidden Ridge development will include retail, restaurants, residential and office space in a transit-oriented setting at build-out, according to the city.
It is located near the intersection of Hidden Ridge and MacArthur Boulevard.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth will have optimal viewing conditions for the first major meteor shower of 2020
summary:
The early birds this weekend may not get the worm, but they could catch a meteor shower.
The Quadrantids meteor shower will be the first major shower of 2020, according to the American Meteor Society.
North Texans interested in seeing the meteor shower will be in luck, as viewing conditions should be optimal.
Next year’s Quadrantids shower will happen during daylight hours for most of the U.S., limiting viewing options.
Timing and moonlight won’t be favorable for viewing in North America again until 2028, according to the meteor society.

title: 2 Dead in Apparent Murder-Suicide in Irving: Police
summary:
Two people are dead after an apparent murder-suicide in Irving on Monday, police say.
According to the Irving Police Department, officers responded to the 1700 block of Piedmont Street at about 6:45 a.m.Police said Jose Luis Reyes shot his wife, Miriam Delilah Reyes, before shooting himself.
Two of the couple's sons, ages 17 and 20, were inside the home at the time, police said.
According to Irving police, the husband and wife were having marital problems, but no domestic violence incidents or offenses were reported to police.

title: 55% of Construction Firms Delaying or Canceling Projects, AGC Survey Shows
summary:
The finding contrasts starkly with the association’s analysis of government data released today that showed a majority of the nation’s metro areas added construction jobs through February.
The association’s analysis of metro employment data showed that construction employment increased between February 2019 and February 2020 in 217 (61 percent) of metro areas, declined in 89, and held steady in 52.
The Dallas-Plano-Irving, Texas, metro added the most construction jobs over 12 months (12,000 jobs, 8 percent), while the largest percentage increase occurred in Walla Walla, Wash. (22 percent, 200 jobs).
The Orange-Rockland-Westchester, N.Y., area lost the most construction jobs over the year (-4,400 jobs, -10 percent).
Association officials said the new February metro employment data, when compared to the recent survey results, demonstrates how quickly construction market conditions have deteriorated because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Irving City Council approves over $560M in bond propositions on May 2 ballot
summary:
The Irving City Council has approved putting over $560 million in bond propositions to voters in the May 2 election.
As approved at the council’s Feb. 13 meeting, the ordinance features 12 different bond propositions rather than a single, large option.
The ordinance for the propositions was approved 8-1, with council member Allan Meagher the lone dissenting vote.
Council member Al Zapanta voted in favor but still expressed concern about inflation and the ability to sell the bonds in coming years.
“My personal opinion is that [the sum of the bond propositions] may be too high, but again it’s not an all-or-nothing vote this time,” he said.

title: Could 2020 see more tornadoes than normal? One forecast says yes
summary:
This year could see more twisters than usual, according to one weather-forecasting service, but North Texas meteorologists are skeptical of that prediction.
AccuWeather predicts an especially active March across the South, a normal April and slightly more tornadoes than normal in May.
On average, 1,253 tornadoes touch down in the U.S. each year.
"A forecast of above-normal tornadoes may lead to someone believing there will be tornadoes dropping out of the sky every day,” Mitchell said.

title: Firefighters Battle 3-Alarm Blaze at Irving Apartment Complex
summary:
Firefighters battled a three-alarm fire at an Irving apartment complex Saturday.
According to Assistant Fire Chief Richard Stewart, the fire was reported just before 11:30 a.m. at the complex in the 1200 block of Meadow Creek Drive.
"It was in the second floor, third floor and then the attic," Stewart said.
No injuries were reported Saturday afternoon, but 10 unites in the complex were impacted and 15 residents displaced.
The blaze was brought under control shortly after 1 p.m.Fire investigators determined the fire started on a first-floor balcony.

summary:

(Courtesy Folio)Irving City Council approved putting forward over $560 million in bond propositions on the May 2 ballot at a Feb. 13 meeting.The bond funds are split among 12 different propositions, with the three largest being a $207 million proposition for street improvements; a $152 million proposition for a joint police and fire department public safety campus; and a $78 million bond for parks, open space and recreation facilities, according to city documents.Early versions of the bond report split the funds among seven propositions, while the approved bond funds are split among 12.

title: Ursula Helen Lefkowitz - Port Arthur News
summary:
Ursula Helen Lefkowitz, 95, of Port Arthur, Texas passed away, Monday, March 16, 2020 at The Medical Center of Southeast Texas in Port Arthur, Texas.
Ursula was born December 6, 1924 in Germany to Fred and Jenny Roos.
She was a resident of Port Arthur for 80 years and a member of Temple Emanuel in Beaumont.
She was the first female member of the North Port Arthur Rotary Club and active for many years in the Port Arthur Little Theatre.
Ursula was preceded in death by her husband, Irving Lefkowitz and cousin, Stephen Roos.

title: US: Western Potatoes grows potato seed for Frito-Lay
summary:
If you’re in the Panhandle and open up a bag of Frito-Lay potato chips, chances are good the potatoes came from one of the Western Potatoes locations in Alliance, Kansas or Colorado, according to an article published by the Star–Herald.
Western Potatoes grows chip potatoes and seed potatoes in Alliance, Lincoln, Kan., and Holyoke, Colorado.
“Frito-Lay owns their own patent on all their seed, all their varieties of potatoes,” Western Potatoes’ Chris Toedtli said.
Seed potatoes have to meet Nebraska certifications, so they are inspected before being sent out to Frito-Lay’s growers across the country.
It gives them more pride, I think.”Read the full article in the Star-Herald herePhoto: Storage buildings at Western Potatoes in Alliance hold potatoes grown specifically for the Frito-Lay company.

title: Office plan would expand Irving’s Toyota Music Factory project
summary:
Developers of Irving’s Toyota Music Factory development want to add office space to the project.
Toyota Music Factory developer Ark Group wants to expand the amount of offices in the Las Colinas mixed-use project by 50%.
The $180 million Music Factory opened in 2018 with a 4,000-seat indoor concert hall, an 8,000-seat outdoor amphitheater, 206,756 square feet of retail and restaurant space, and a 100,000-square-foot office building.
Before it was finished, the existing office building was fully leased to Ethos Group, a private firm that provides franchised automotive dealerships across the United States.
The office space in the building would grow from 100,000 to 152,387 square feet, according to a zoning request with the city of Irving.

title: Has Dallas-Fort Worth seen its last freeze of the season?
summary:
Lows in the 30s aren’t in the forecast for Dallas-Fort Worth in the near future, and, historically, the average date of the last freeze — March 12 — is near.
On average, Dallas-Fort Worth gets about two freezes in the month of March.
Dallas-Fort Worth has recorded a freeze as late into the year as April 13, which has happened in 1997 and 1957, according to the National Weather Service.
Last year, Dallas-Fort Worth got its last freeze of the season on March 6, according to the weather service.
So, I think our chance for another freeze is very low.”In 2017, Dallas-Fort Worth recorded the earliest last freeze of the season on Jan. 8, when the temperature dropped to 20 degrees.

AUSTIN — A state agency has moved to prevent day care centers across Texas from closing as the new coronavirus begins to threaten the paychecks of low-income working parents.
The Texas Workforce Commission on Tuesday voted unanimously to direct local workforce boards to ignore children’s absences and parents’ missed payments in federally subsidized child care.

summary:

There, as with Pioneer, Benderson Development owns the land beneath the regional mall, which is anchored by Saks Fifth Avenue, Dillard’s and others.

title: 2 Hurt, 1 Killed in Construction Accident at New Irving Frito-Lay Facility Friday
summary:
A construction worker was killed and two others were injured Friday at a Frito-Lay site in Irving, police say.
The accident took place at a building under construction on the Frito Lay property at 701 North Wildwood Drive, near Loop 12 and Union Bower Road, at about 1 p.m.
Officer Robert Reeves, with the Irving Police Department, said two ladders collided, causing three men to fall as far as 30 feet.
One of the men died, Reeves said, while the other two were injured and hospitalized at Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas.
According to police, all of the men involved are in their 30s and are employees of Walker Engineering, the contractor hired to build the facility.

Microsoft opened the campus in the Las Colinas district in 2001.
Most of the new jobs being created will “require a high degree of technical ability to support operations,” a Microsoft spokeswoman said.

The Dallas-Plano-Irving, Texas, metro added the most construction jobs over 12 months (12,000 jobs, 8 percent), while the largest percentage increase occurred in Walla Walla, Wash. (22 percent, 200 jobs).
The Orange-Rockland-Westchester, N.Y., area lost the most construction jobs over the year (-4,400 jobs, -10 percent).

title: Could it be a snowy winter for Dallas-Fort Worth? Here’s what the new Farmer’s Almanac says
summary:
As warm weather lingers over North Texas, it might be hard to believe that winter is coming.
The 2020 edition of The Old Farmer's Almanac predicts a milder, drier winter than normal for portions of Texas and Oklahoma, but it's not counting out a chance for snow.
The almanac predicts the best chances for snow in Oklahoma and North Texas, including Dallas-Fort Worth, are in early December, early to mid-January and mid-February.
North Texas saw its first snowflakes of 2019 on Jan. 19.
The almanac also predicts the coldest periods of the winter will arrive in late December, late January and mid-February.

There were also 18 hospitalizations from Dec. 22 to Dec. 28.Public health officials are also urging residents to take antiviral medications if they experience flu symptoms and to take preventative actions, such as covering coughs and washing hands, according to the news release.The Dallas County Health and Human Services department has confirmed five flu-related deaths in the 2019-20 season.Most recently, the DCHHS confirmed Jan. 7 that an 85-year-old resident of Cedar Hill died from flu-related causes.“We have seen an early increase in flu activity in Dallas this season,” said Dr. Philip Huang, the DCHHS director and health authority.
"While we cannot predict the severity or duration of the flu season from year to year, the best way to protect yourself and others is to get your flu vaccine.”The DCHHS has also reported the flu-related deaths of a 79-year-old Irving resident with pre-existing medical conditions, as well as a 36-year-old Dallas resident.Tarrant County has also tracked widespread flu activity.

title: Could fracking be causing earthquakes throughout the state? Curious Texas digs in.
summary:
North Texas has long been known for its destructive tornadoes and fierce thunderstorms, but earthquakes?
“I think that for people who live in North Texas, the earthquakes were alarming,” DeShon said.
West TexasJust as North Texas’ seismicity has slowed since 2016, western and southern Texas have become more earthquake-active, DeShon said.
But in a recent study, Savvaidis and his team at the University of Texas at Austin found that many West Texas quakes are caused by fracking itself.
Between 2014 and 2018, upward of 85% of South Texas earthquakes in the Eagle Ford Shale Play were linked to fracking activity, according to the Houston Chronicle.

... [Light industrial is] office warehouse and distribution and light manufacturing.”City master plans dating back into the early 1970s drew a clear line between the eastern, residential and western, industrial sides of town.
“While there is some residential on the west side, the majority of the land is open space or commercial.”The majority of Coppell’s industrial district falls within a zone that reaches an average annual day and night noise level of 65 decibels.
While not ideal for residential development, the area is attractive to global corporations.“Once McLaren North America made the decision to relocate to the Dallas area, Coppell became an immediate consideration,” Joseph said in the statement.
“Additionally, we will host customers and dealers [at] our facilities for various events, including launch events, and the desirability of the area was a key consideration.”Other major business operations in the industrial district include a Subaru parts distribution center, the U.S.

title: NYE at PY1 Nights - the New Immersive Nightlife Experience
summary:
Ring in 2020 at PY1 Nights and fall into the wonder-inspiring thematic world of POP -- an immersive experience of urban art and animation celebrating the spirit of street culture on a gigantic dance floor.

title: Hidden Ridge developer to pay for building costs of new Irving transit station
summary:
Irving City Council has amended an economic incentive agreement worth $24.3 million with the developer of the Hidden Ridge mixed-use project.The amended agreement stipulates that the developer pay for building costs of a new Dallas Area Rapid Transit light rail station .
That station will be located along the Orange Line near Pioneer Natural Resource’s campus between Carpenter Ranch Road and Green Park Drive, and it is expected to be complete in December.The amended agreement also provides for additional economic incentives that would be unlocked upon the developer’s completion of additional construction projects.The Hidden Ridge development will include retail, restaurants, residential and office space in a transit-oriented setting at build-out, according to the city.
It is located near the intersection of Hidden Ridge and MacArthur Boulevard.
